thread.title: Victorian Liberal Party 'furious' over missing $1.5m
thread.title_full: Victorian Liberal Party 'furious' over missing $1.5m | afr.com

author: Post to Linkedin
title: Victorian Liberal Party 'furious' over missing $1.5m
text:
Michael Kroger: "He was able to get away with it for a very long time." Justin McManus Share on twitter by Lucille Keen A senior Victorian Liberal Party official has been accused by the party of embezzling $1.5 million in funds from the party, with some believed to be invested on the sharemarket.
Former party state director Damien Mantach has allegedly been involved in a number of unauthorised transactions which saw $1.5 million transferred from the party to accounts associated to him.
The transactions were uncovered after Victorian Liberal Party president Michael Kroger launched an audit into the party's spending at the last election campaign.
Mr Kroger said the accounts showed that a number of unauthorised transactions associated with Mr Mantach took place between 2010 and 2014.
Former Liberal Party state director Damien Mantach. "Some weeks ago we initially identified some of these transactions through a comprehensive internal audit, and have further investigated these transactions through a special audit conducted by independent forensic accountants, PPB Advisory," he said.
"We will allege that Mr Mantach has defrauded the party of around $1.5 million."
Mr Mantach is yet to respond to the allegations.​
Fraud squad The Liberal Party has referred the matter to Victoria Police.
In a statement Victoria Police said the fraud and extortion squad were aware of an external investigation into the alleged disappearance of funds from a Victorian government party.
"The matter has been reported to police and will be investigated by the Fraud and Extortion Squad," the statement said.
Mr Kroger claims it understood the funds were spent on "nothing particularly outrageous or exciting", rather on "lifestyle", and he suspects some of the funds have been invested.
It is understood some of the money was used to buy shares and the party hopes it can recover some of it.
An ASIC search shows Mr Mantach's wife Jodie registered a company called Mantach Enterprises in February 2014.
However, Mr Kroger has said it was believed Mr Mantach acted alone and no other party officials or family members were involved.
Mr Mantach is the son of a former Tasmanian Liberal Party state president Brian Mantach, a role he later held before the Victorian branch.
He has also worked for the Howard government, for former federal industrial relations minister Peter Reith.
In 2001 he was moved into the government's central media team.
Mr Mantach resigned as Victorian state director in March following the Liberal's election defeat and the appointment of Mr Kroger.
He was one of the Liberals who was covertly recorded during the 2013 tapes scandal that saw former premier Ted Baillieu forced to resign.
Mr Kroger said it was regrettable the alleged missing funds were not detected earlier.
Victorian Liberal Party branch treasurer Andrew Abercrombie refused to answer questions from the media on Thursday and left the party headquarters after an administrative meeting, hiding his face with a briefcase.
Mr Kroger said all organisations were to some extent at risk of this sort of activity.
'Furious': Matthew Guy He said the party would be implementing new systems.
Liberal leader Matthew Guy said the party was formally advised this week .
"It's fair to say the party is furious," Mr Guy said.
"We want our money back. We want this matter sent to the police and we will be doing everything to ensure that justice is done. I saw someone making a comment that we were white hot with anger – that's just the start of it."
